A Nice Labelling for Tree-Like
Event Structures of Degree 333

Luigi Santocanale
Abstract

We address the problem of finding nice labellings for event structures of degree 333. We develop a minimum theory by which we prove that the labelling number of an event structure of degree 333 is bounded by a linear function of the height. The main theorem we present in this paper states that event structures of degree 333 whose causality order is a tree have a nice labelling with 333 colors. Finally, we exemplify how to use this theorem to construct upper bounds for the labelling number of other event structures of degree 333.

1 Introduction

Event structures, introduced in [1], are nowadays a widely recognized model of true concurrent computation and have found many uses since then. They are an intermediate abstract model that make it possible to relate other more concrete models such as Petri Nets or higher dimensional automata [2]. They provide formal semantics of process calculi [3, 4]. More recently, logicians became interested in event structures with the aim of constructing models of proof systems that are invariant under the equalities induced by the cut elimination procedure [5, 6].

Our interest for event structures stems from the fact that they combine distinct approaches to the modeling of concurrent computation. On one side, language theorists have developed the theory of partially commutative monoids [7] as the basic language to approach concurrency. On the other hand, the framework of domain theory and, ultimately, order theoretic ideas have often been proposed as the proper tools to handle concurrency, see for example [8]. In this paper we pursue a combinatorial problem that lies at the intersection of these two approaches. It is the problem of finding nice labellings for event structures of fixed degree. To our knowledge, this problem has not been investigated any longer since it was posed and partially solved in [9].

Let us recall that an event structure is made up of a set of local events Eğ¸E which is ordered by a causality relation â‰¤\leq. Moreover, a concurrency relation âŒ¢âŒ¢\frown, that may only relate causally independent events, is given. A global state of the computation is modeled as a clique of the concurrency relation. Global states may be organized into a poset, the coherent domain of an event structure, which represents all the concurrent non-deterministic executions of a system. Roughly speaking, the nice labelling problem consists in representing the coherent domain of an event structure as a poset of traces or, more precisely, pomsets. That is, such a domain should be reconstructed using the standard ingredients of trace theory: an alphabet Î£Î£\Sigma, a local independence relation Iğ¼I, and a prefix closed subset of the free monoid Lğ¿L, see [10, 11]. By the general theory relating traces to ordered sets, the problem always has a solution (Î£,I,L)Î£ğ¼ğ¿(\Sigma,I,L). We are asked to find a solution with the cardinality of the alphabet Î£Î£\Sigma minimal. The problem is actually equivalent to a graph coloring problem in that we can associate to an event structure a graph, of which we are asked to compute the chromatic number. The degree of an event structure is the maximal number of upper covers of some elements in the associated domain. Under the graph theoretic translation of the problem, the degree coincides with the clique number, and therefore it is a lower bound for the cardinality of a solution. A main contribution in [9] was to prove that event structures of degree 222 have a nice labelling with 222 letters, i.e. they have a solution (Î£,I,L)Î£ğ¼ğ¿(\Sigma,I,L) with cardâ€‹(Î£)=2cardÎ£2\mathrm{card}(\Sigma)=2. On the other hand, it was proved there that event structures of higher degrees may require more letters than the degree.

The labelling problem may be thought to be a generalization of the problem of covering a poset by disjoint chains. Dilworthâ€™s Theorem [12] states that the minimal cardinality of such a cover equals the maximal cardinality of an antichain. This theorem and the results of [9] constitute the few knowledge on the problem presently available to us. For example, we cannot state that there is some fixed k>nğ‘˜ğ‘›k>n for which every event structure of degree nğ‘›n has a nice labelling with at most kğ‘˜k letters. In light of standard graph theoretic results [13], the above statement should not be taken for granted.

We present here our first results on the nice labelling problem for event structures of degree 333. We develop a minimum theory that shows that the graph of a degree 333 event structure, when restricted to an antichain, is almost acyclic and can be colored with 333 letters. This observation allows to construct an upper bound to the labelling number of such event structure as a linear function of its height. We prove then our main theorem stating that event structures of degree 333, whose causality order is a tree, have a nice labelling with 333 letters. Let us just say that such an event structure may represent a concurrent system where some processes are only allowed to fork or to take local nondeterministic choices. Finally, we exemplify how to use this theorem to construct upper bounds for the labelling number of other event structures of degree 333. In some simple cases, we obtain constant upper bounds to the labelling number, i.e. upper bounds that are functions of no parameter.

While these results do not answer the general problem, that of computing the labelling number of degree 333 event structures, we are aware that graph coloring problems may be difficult to answer. Thus we decided to present these results and share the knowledge so far acquired and also to encourage other researchers to pursue the problem. Let us mention why we believe that this and other problems in the combinatorics of concurrency deserve to be deeply investigated. The theory of event structures is now being applied within verification. A model checker, POEM, presently developed in Marseilles, makes explicit use of trace theory and of the theory of partial orders to represent the state space of a concurrent system [14]. The combinatorics of posets is there exploited to achieve an the efficient exploration of the global states of concurrent systems [15]. Thus, having a solid theoretical understanding of such combinatorics is, for us, a prerequisite and a complement for designing efficient algorithms for these kind of tools.

The paper is structured as follows. After recalling the order theoretic concepts we shall use, we introduce event structures and the nice labelling problem in section 2. In section 3 we develop the first properties of event structures of degree 333. As a result, we devise an upper bound for the labelling number of such event structures as a linear function of the height. In section 4 we present our main result stating that event structures whose underlying order is a tree may be labeled with 333 colors. In section 5 we develop a general approach to construct upper bounds to the labelling number of event structures of degree 333. Using this approach and the results of the previous section, we compute a constant upper bound for a class of degree 333 event structures that have some simplifying properties and which are consequently called simple.

2 Event Structures and the Nice Labelling Problem

Event structures are a basic model of concurrency introduced in [1]. The definition we present here is from [2].

A coherent event structure is completely described by a triple âŸ¨E,â‰¤,âŒ¢âŸ©ğ¸âŒ¢\langle E,\leq,\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\rangle where the latter is a symmetric relation subject to the following condition: xâŒ¢yâŒ¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¦x\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}y and zâ‰¤xğ‘§ğ‘¥z\leq x implies zâŒ¢yâŒ¢ğ‘§ğ‘¦z\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}y or zâ‰¤yğ‘§ğ‘¦z\leq y. In this paper we shall deal with coherent event structures only and, from now on, event structure will be a synonym for coherent event structure.

We shall focus mainly on the orthogonality relation. Let us observe that two orthogonal elements are called independent in [9]. We prefer however not to use this naming: we shall frequently make use of standard graph theoretic language and argue about cliques, not on their dual, independent sets. The orthogonality relation clearly is symmetric and moreover it inherits from the concurrency relation the following property: if xâ€‹âŒ¢Â¯â€‹yğ‘¥Â¯âŒ¢ğ‘¦x{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y and zâ‰¤xğ‘§ğ‘¥z\leq x, then zâ€‹âŒ¢Â¯â€‹yğ‘§Â¯âŒ¢ğ‘¦z{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y or zâ‰¤yğ‘§ğ‘¦z\leq y.

Definition 3

A nice labelling of an event structure â„°â„°\mathcal{E} is a pair (Î»,Î£)ğœ†Î£(\lambda,\Sigma), where Î£Î£\Sigma is a finite alphabet and Î»:EâŸ¶Î£:ğœ†âŸ¶ğ¸Î£\lambda:E\longrightarrow\Sigma is such that Î»â€‹(x)â‰ Î»â€‹(y)ğœ†ğ‘¥ğœ†ğ‘¦\lambda(x)\neq\lambda(y) whenever xâ€‹âŒ¢Â¯â€‹yğ‘¥Â¯âŒ¢ğ‘¦x{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y.

To understand the origins of this problem, let us recall the definition of the domain of an event structure.

Definition 4

The domain ğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ’Ÿâ„°\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) of an event structure â„°=âŸ¨E,â‰¤,ğ’âŸ©â„°ğ¸ğ’\mathcal{E}=\langle E,\leq,\mathcal{C}\rangle is the collection of lower sets in ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}, ordered by subset inclusion.

Following a standard axiomatization in theoretical computer science [2] ğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ’Ÿâ„°\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) is a stable domain which is coherent if â„°â„°\mathcal{E} is coherent. Stable means that ğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ’Ÿâ„°\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) is essentially a distributive lattice. As a matter of fact, if â„°â„°\mathcal{E} is finite, then a possible alternative axiomatization of the poset ğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ’Ÿâ„°\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) is as follows. It is easily seen that the collection ğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ’Ÿâ„°\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) is closed under binary intersections, hence it is a finite meet semilattice without a top element, a chopped lattice in the sense of [16, Chapter 4]. Also the chopped lattice is distributive, meaning that whenever X,Y,Zâˆˆğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘ğ’Ÿâ„°X,Y,Z\in\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) and XâˆªYâˆˆğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ’Ÿâ„°X\cup Y\in\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}), then Zâˆ©(XâˆªY)=(Zâˆ©X)âˆª(Zâˆ©Y)ğ‘ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘ğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘ŒZ\cap(X\cup Y)=(Z\cap X)\cup(Z\cap Y). It can be shown that every distributive chopped lattice is isomorphic to the domain of a finite â€“ not necessarily coherent â€“ event structure.

Lemma 1

A set {x1,â€¦,xn}subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\{\,x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\,\} is a clique in the graph ğ’¢â€‹(â„°)ğ’¢â„°\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}) iff there exists Iâˆˆğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ¼ğ’Ÿâ„°I\in\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) such that Iâˆª{xi}ğ¼subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–I\cup\{\,x_{i}\,\}, i=1,â€¦,nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›i=1,\ldots,n, are distinct upper covers of Iğ¼I in the domain ğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ’Ÿâ„°\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}).

The Lemma shows that a nice labelling Î»:EâŸ¶Î£:ğœ†âŸ¶ğ¸Î£\lambda:E\longrightarrow\Sigma allows to label the edges of the Hasse diagram of ğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ’Ÿâ„°\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) so that: (i) outgoing edges from the same source vertex have distinct labels, (ii) perspective edges â€“ i.e. edges I0â‰ºI1precedessubscriptğ¼0subscriptğ¼1I_{0}\prec I_{1} and J0â‰ºJ1precedessubscriptğ½0subscriptğ½1J_{0}\prec J_{1} such that I0=I1âˆ©J0subscriptğ¼0subscriptğ¼1subscriptğ½0I_{0}=I_{1}\cap J_{0} and J1=I1âˆªJ0subscriptğ½1subscriptğ¼1subscriptğ½0J_{1}=I_{1}\cup J_{0} â€“ have the same label. These conditions are necessary and sufficient to show that ğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ’Ÿâ„°\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) is order isomorphic to a consistent (but not complete) set of Pğ‘ƒP-traces (or pomsets) on the alphabet Î£Î£\Sigma in the sense of [10].

The degree of an event structure â„°â„°\mathcal{E} is the degree of the domain ğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ’Ÿâ„°\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}), that is, the maximum number of upper covers of a lower set Iğ¼I within the poset ğ’Ÿâ€‹(â„°)ğ’Ÿâ„°\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}). Lemma 1 shows that the degree of â„°â„°\mathcal{E} is equal to the size of a maximal clique in ğ’¢â€‹(â„°)ğ’¢â„°\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}), i.e. to the clique number of ğ’¢â€‹(â„°)ğ’¢â„°\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}). Henceforth, the degree of â„°â„°\mathcal{E} is a lower bound to Î³â€‹(ğ’¢â€‹(â„°))ğ›¾ğ’¢â„°\gamma(\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E})). The following Theorems state the few results on the nice labelling problem that are available in the literature.

Theorem 2.1 (see [12])

Let ğ’©â€‹ğ’nğ’©subscriptğ’ğ‘›\mathcal{NC}_{n} be the class of event structures of degree at most nğ‘›n with empty conflict relation. Then Î³â€‹(ğ’©â€‹ğ’n)=nğ›¾ğ’©subscriptğ’ğ‘›ğ‘›\gamma(\mathcal{NC}_{n})=n.

Theorem 2.2 (see [9])

Let ğ’¦nsubscriptğ’¦ğ‘›\mathcal{K}_{n} be the class of event structures of degree at most nğ‘›n. Then Î³â€‹(ğ’¦n)=nğ›¾subscriptğ’¦ğ‘›ğ‘›\gamma(\mathcal{K}_{n})=n if nâ‰¤2ğ‘›2n\leq 2 and Î³â€‹(ğ’¦n)â‰¥n+1ğ›¾subscriptğ’¦ğ‘›ğ‘›1\gamma(\mathcal{K}_{n})\geq n+1 otherwise.

The last theorem has been our starting point for investigating the nice labelling problem for event structures of degree 333.

3 Cycles and Antichains

From now own, in this and the following sections, â„°=âŸ¨E,â‰¤,ğ’âŸ©â„°ğ¸ğ’\mathcal{E}=\langle E,\leq,\mathcal{C}\rangle will denote a coherent event structure of degree at most 333. We begin our investigation of the nice labelling problem by studying the restriction to an antichain of the graph ğ’¢â€‹(â„°)ğ’¢â„°\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}). The main tool we shall use is the following Lemma. It is a straightforward generalization of [9, Lemma 2.2] to degree 333. In [17] we proposed generalizations of this Lemma to higher degrees, pointing out their strong geometrical flavor.

Corollary 1

Any subgraph of ğ’¢â€‹(â„°)ğ’¢â„°\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}) induced by an antichain can be colored with 333 colors.

Proof

Since the only cycles have length at most 333, such an induced graph is chordal and its clique number is 333. It is well known that the chromatic number of chordal graphs equals their clique number [18]. âˆ

In the rest of this section we exploit the previous observations to construct upper bounds for the labelling number of â„°â„°\mathcal{E}. We remark that these upper bounds might appear either too abstract, or too trivial. On the other hand, we believe that they well illustrate the kind of problems that arise when trying to build complex event structures that might have labelling number greater than 444.

4 An Optimal Nice Labelling for Trees and Forests

We prove in this section the main contribution of this paper. Assuming that âŸ¨E,â‰¤âŸ©ğ¸\langle E,\leq\rangle is a tree or a forest, then we define a labelling with 333 colors, and prove it is a nice labelling. Since clearly we can construct a tree which needs at least three colors, such a labelling is optimal. Before defining the labelling, we shall develop a small amount of observations.

Definition 5

We say that two distinct events are twins if they have the same set of lower covers.

Clearly if x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y are twins, then z<xğ‘§ğ‘¥z<x if and only if z<yğ‘§ğ‘¦z<y. More importantly, if x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y are twins, then the relation xâ€‹âŒ¢Â¯â€‹yğ‘¥Â¯âŒ¢ğ‘¦x{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y holds. As a matter of fact, if xâ€²<xsuperscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘¥x^{\prime}<x then xâ€²<ysuperscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘¦x^{\prime}<y, hence xâ€²â€‹âŒ¢ â‰ƒ â€‹ysuperscriptğ‘¥â€²âŒ¢ â‰ƒ ğ‘¦x^{\prime}\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\parbox{10.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{-7.0pt}{$\simeq$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}y. Similarly, if yâ€²<ysuperscriptğ‘¦â€²ğ‘¦y^{\prime}<y then yâ€²â€‹âŒ¢ â‰ƒ â€‹xsuperscriptğ‘¦â€²âŒ¢ â‰ƒ ğ‘¥y^{\prime}\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\parbox{10.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{-7.0pt}{$\simeq$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}x. It follows that a set of events having the same lower covers form a clique in ğ’¢â€‹(â„°)ğ’¢â„°\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}), hence it has at most the degree of an event structure, 333 in the present case. To introduce the next Lemmas, if xâˆˆYâŠ†Eğ‘¥ğ‘Œğ¸x\in Y\subseteq E, define

OxYsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‚ğ‘Œğ‘¥\displaystyle O^{Y}_{x} ={z|zâ€‹âŒ¢Â¯â€‹xâ€‹Â andÂ â€‹yâ‰°z,Â forallÂ â€‹yâˆˆY}.absentconditional-setğ‘§formulae-sequencenot-less-than-or-equalsğ‘§Â¯âŒ¢ğ‘¥Â andÂ ğ‘¦ğ‘§Â forallÂ ğ‘¦ğ‘Œ\displaystyle=\{\,z\,|\,z{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}x\textrm{ and }y\not\leq z,\text{ forall }y\in Y\,\}\,.

If Y={x,y}ğ‘Œğ‘¥ğ‘¦Y=\{\,x,y\,\}, then we shall abuse of notation and write Oxx,ysubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‚ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¥O^{x,y}_{x}, Oxy,xsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‚ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¥O^{y,x}_{x} as synonyms of OxYsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‚ğ‘Œğ‘¥O^{Y}_{x}. Lemma 3

The obvious corollary of Proposition 3 is that if â„°â„°\mathcal{E} is already a sort of tree, then it has a nice labelling with 333 letters. We state this fact as the following Theorem, after we having made precise the meaning of the phrase â€œâ„°â„°\mathcal{E} is a sort of tree.â€

Definition 8

Theorem 4.1

The labelling number of the class â„±3subscriptâ„±3\mathcal{F}_{3} is 333.

As a matter of fact, let â„°â„°\mathcal{E} be a forest, and consider the event structure â„°âŠ¥subscriptâ„°bottom\mathcal{E}_{\bot} obtained from â„°â„°\mathcal{E} by adding a new bottom element âŠ¥bottom\bot. 5 More Upper Bounds

The results presented in the previous section exemplify a remarkable property of event structures of degree 333: many types of subsets of events induce a subgraph of ğ’¢â€‹(â„°)ğ’¢â„°\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}) that can be colored with 333 colors. It might be asked whether this property can be exploited to construct nice labellings. The positive answer comes from a standard technique in graph theory [19]. Consider a partition ğ’«={[z]âˆ£zâˆˆE}ğ’«conditional-setdelimited-[]ğ‘§ğ‘§ğ¸{\cal P}=\{\,[z]\mid z\in E\,\} of the set of events such that each equivalence class [z]delimited-[]ğ‘§[z] has a labelling with 333 letters. Proposition 4

If the graph ğ’¢â€‹(ğ’«,â„°)ğ’¢ğ’«â„°\mathcal{G}({\cal P},\mathcal{E}) is nğ‘›n-coloriable, then â„°â„°\mathcal{E} has a labelling with 3â€‹n3ğ‘›3n colors.

Proof

The reader should remark that Proposition 4 generalizes Proposition 2. The Proposition also suggests that a finite upper bound for the labelling number of event structures of degree 333 might indeed exist.

Â Â  We conclude the paper by exemplifying how to use the Labelling Theorem on trees and the previous Lemma to construct a finite upper bound for the labelling number of event structures that we call simple due to their additional simplifying properties. Consider the event structure on the right and name it ğ’®ğ’®{\cal S}. In this picture we have used dotted lines for the edges of the Hasse

diagram of âŸ¨E,â‰¤âŸ©ğ¸\langle E,\leq\rangle, simple lines for maximal concurrent pairs, and double lines for minimal conflicts. Concurrent pairs xâŒ¢yâŒ¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¦x\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}y that are not maximal, i.e. for which there exists xâ€²,yâ€²superscriptğ‘¥â€²superscriptğ‘¦â€²x^{\prime},y^{\prime} such that xâ€²â€‹âŒ¢Â¯â€‹yâ€²superscriptğ‘¥â€²Â¯âŒ¢superscriptğ‘¦â€²x^{\prime}{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y^{\prime} and either x<xâ€²ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²x<x^{\prime} or y<yâ€²ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘¦â€²y<y^{\prime}, are not drawn. We leave the reader to verify that a nice labelling of ğ’®ğ’®{\cal S} needs at least 444 letters. On the other hand, it shouldnâ€™t be difficult to see that a nice labelling with 444 letters exists. To obtain it, take apart events with at most 111 lower cover from the others, as suggested in the picture. Use then the results of the previous section to label with three letters the elements with at most one lower cover, and label the only element with two lower covers with a forth letter.

A formalization of this intuitive method leads to the following Definition and Proposition.

Definition 9

We say that an event structure is simple if

  1. 1.

    it is graded, i.e. 0â€‹pâ€‹tâ€‹(x)=0â€‹pâ€‹tâ€‹(y)âˆ’10ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¥0ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¦10pt(x)=0pt(y)-1 whenever xâ‰ºyprecedesğ‘¥ğ‘¦x\prec y,

  2. 2.

    every size 333 clique of ğ’¢â€‹(â„°)ğ’¢â„°\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}) contains a minimal conflict.

The event structure ğ’®ğ’®{\cal S} is simple and proves that even simple event structures cannot be labeled with just 333 letters.

Proposition 5

Every simple event structure of degree 333 has a nice labelling with 121212 letters.
